author: By Kate Zernike
title: Ohio Moves Closer to Ballot Issue That Would Protect Abortion Rights
description: Supporters of protecting abortion in the state’s Constitution submitted enough signatures to get on the November ballot. But another vote in August could make it harder to win.
content: Ohio moved one step closer to becoming the next big test case in the nation’s fight over abortion, after supporters of a measure that would ask voters to establish a right to abortion in the state’s Constitution this week said they had filed more than enough signatures to put it on the ballot in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: What Men Should Know Before Coloring Their Hair
description: After new photos showed Bill de Blasio sporting noticeably darker hair than he had in his days as mayor, hairstylists offered tips for dyeing with dignity.
content: A change in hair color can be emblematic of a shift in someone’s personal life, a fresh start or an attempt to hit pause on the aging process. Depending on the person, it may be a significant change that lasts for a while — or just till the next haircut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Faces a Diplomatic Test in Her High-Stakes Visit to China
description: The Treasury secretary will need to defend export controls and tariffs while explaining that the United States does not aim to harm China’s economy.
content: At her confirmation hearing in early 2021, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen struck a tough tone on China, describing it as America’s most important strategic competitor and pledging to confront its “abusive, unfair and illegal practices” that she said were harming businesses and workers in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: With a Creative Edit, the Wisconsin Governor Raised School Funding. For 400 Years.
description: Gov. Tony Evers used a quirky rule to edit the state budget and raise the cap on public school funding — until the year 2425.
content: It took only a few snips of creative editing for Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin to push through a long-term boost to public education funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Azeen Ghorayshi and Jamie Kelter Davis
title: Fight or Flight: Transgender Care Bans Leave Families and Doctors Scrambling
description: Laws in 20 states have left the fate of clinics in doubt and families with transgender children searching for medical care across state lines.
content: David and Wendy Batchelder hate the thought of putting their spacious house in West Des Moines, Iowa, on the market, disrupting the routines of their six children or giving up the Lutheran church that they have attended for roughly a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Roadblocks to Sweden’s NATO Membership, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: In his new spotlight, the Belarusian leader could gain leverage.
description: The brief mutiny by the Wagner mercenary force last month has given Belarus’s autocratic leader Aleksandr G. Lukashenko an opening to upend his subservient relationship with Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: ‘Happy Together,’ Yet Still Indifferent About Marriage
description: Dianne Cox and Michael Cammer, who had been together for almost 25 years before saying “I do,” both struggle with traditional labels after six years of marriage.
content: Dianne Cox and Michael Cammer don’t particularly like being married, which is not to say they dislike it. Mostly, it doesn’t matter to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: The Mayor Had a Photo of a Fallen Officer. Was His Story About It True?
description: Mayor Eric Adams has often talked about a wrinkled photo of a fallen police officer that he kept in his wallet. Now that photo and the story have been called into question.
content: In Mayor Eric Adams’s first month in office, he was confronted with a tragic crisis: the deaths of two New York City police officers who were responding to a domestic disturbance in Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juston Jones
title: Zelensky said he warned allies the counteroffensive would proceed slowly amid the wait for weapons.
description: Ukraine’s president said he had wanted to start the military push sooner, in an interview with CNN.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said he had warned the United States and other Western nations that the counteroffensive would go slowly the longer it took allies to deliver the promised weapons and ammunition needed for the mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: U.S. Expected to Provide Cluster Munitions to Ukraine, Official Says
description: Ukraine has pressed the United States to supply it with the munitions. Here’s a guide to why this type of weapon is controversial and widely banned — and why Kyiv wants it.
content: The United States is expected to announce that it will provide Ukraine with cluster munitions, a senior Biden administration official said. Kyiv has been pushing for the controversial and widely banned type of weapon but Washington has resisted because of its potential to cause indiscriminate harm to civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford’s U.S. Sales Rose 10% in the Second Quarter
description: The automaker saw a big jump in deliveries of pickup trucks as demand from consumers and businesses remained strong.
content: Ford Motor said Thursday that its new-vehicle sales rose 10 percent in the three months of April through June, thanks to robust demand for trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: Vivante
description: Carrie attends a former mentor’s party, where she meets a longtime personal hero. Miranda gets a charley horse.
content: Remember back in Episode 2 this season when Carrie could barely bring herself to say “vagina”? It turns out that same squeamishness doesn’t apply to the word for male ejaculate that rhymes with “whiz.” Carrie says it not once, not twice, but a cringetastic four times — in a row — at the lunch table she shares with Charlotte, Miranda and Anthony (Mario Cantone) in Episode 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The League’ Review: A Crucial Baseball Legacy
description: Sam Pollard’s new documentary traces the history of the Negro leagues.
content: If you thought that Jackie Robinson was the first Black player in professional baseball, “The League” would like to offer a correction. Moses Fleetwood Walker became a catcher for the Toledo Blue Stockings in 1884, before organized baseball was segregated and more than 60 years before Robinson broke the major leagues’ color line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Are These the Most Expensive Jeans in the World?
description: Valentino and Balenciaga make the case that sometimes the most spectacular clothes are the hardest to recognize — and replicate. Chanel takes it easy.
content: At around peak rush hour on the penultimate day of the couture shows a line of black cars snaked out of Paris, past grassy fields and factories 30 miles north to the 16th-century Château de Chantilly. Guests in brightly colored plumage were disgorged to teeter down a long stone walkway that opened to a vista of reflecting pools and manicured lawns set around a central fountain surrounded by a labyrinth of benches. That was where, as golden hour set in, a magic Valentino show began — with Kaia Gerber in a pair of jeans and a white shirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: New Federal Decisions Make Alzheimer’s Drug Leqembi Widely Accessible
description: The F.D.A. gave full approval to the drug, but added a black-box warning about safety risks. Medicare said it would cover most of the high cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: U.S. Animal Industries Pose Disease Risks to People, Report Says
description: The nation uses an enormous number of animals for commercial purposes, and regulations do not adequately protect against outbreaks, experts concluded.
content: The United States is home to an enormous array of animal industries — including industrial agriculture, fur farming and the exotic pet trade — that pose a significant risk of creating infectious disease outbreaks in humans, according to a new report by experts at Harvard Law School and New York University. Moreover, the nation “has no comprehensive strategy” to mitigate the dangers posed by these practices, many of which operate with little regulation and out of public view, the authors concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Why I Still Love the New York Mets
description: We don’t watch sports for happiness; we watch for the human drama.
content: Chip … chip … chip. I can feel the New York Mets chiseling out a piece of my soul every week. A blown lead here … chip. A dropped pop-up there … chip. Getting swept at home by an utterly mediocre rival … chip. Maybe you remember that tale of Prometheus chained to a rock, while an eagle comes by every day to rip out his liver. I can relate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Nicole Sperling
title: NBC’s New Chief Overhauls Top Ranks
description: Donna Langley will gain broader oversight of creative decisions for entertainment content, and Mark Lazarus and Cesar Conde are both getting additional responsibilities.
content: Mike Cavanagh is beginning to put his stamp on NBCUniversal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Life After Password Sharing
description: A reader’s access to a streaming service has been cut off. Should she pay for her own account?
content: Hannah writes: I shared a streaming-service account with my mom. But we’ve been cut off thanks to the company’s new password-sharing restrictions. I want to pay for a new account. But my partner, Bobby, doesn’t want to reward this company’s behavior. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Bum Knees, Stress Fractures and Mental Anguish. Oh, Canada.
description: Canada has been striving to become a top tennis nation for two decades, and with two Wimbledon finals appearances and a U.S. Open title it seemed to be working. Then things quieted down.
content: It may be a little hard to remember, with all the injuries, career detours and mystifying losses, but there was a time when everything seemed possible for Canadian tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Aide Pleads Not Guilty in Classified Documents Case
description: Walt Nauta, the former president’s personal aide, entered his plea in federal court in Miami. He is charged with conspiring to obstruct the government’s efforts to retrieve highly sensitive material.
content: Walt Nauta, a personal aide to former President Donald J. Trump, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to federal charges of conspiring with Mr. Trump to obstruct the government’s monthslong efforts to retrieve a trove of highly sensitive national security documents from the former president after he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At Wimbledon, Sofia Kenin Rediscovers Her Fighting Form
description: With her straight-sets win over Xinyu Wang on Thursday, Kenin had won a second consecutive match for only the fourth time all year.
content: It has been three and a half years since Sofia Kenin put both hands to her face and teared up in Melbourne. That night, she had just won the Australian Open at 21, highlighting to the world her ferocious will to fight for every point, every shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Eagles Join Parade of Acts on Final Tours With a ‘Long Goodbye’
description: The band, which performed a “farewell” tour in 2003, will begin what’s billed as a last run of dates in September.
content: Eagles are touring for the last time. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Court Acquits Police Officer Who Killed Autistic Palestinian Man
description: The shooting of the man, Iyad al-Hallaq, who was killed in May 2020, around the same time as George Floyd, cast a light on police violence.
content: An Israeli court on Thursday acquitted a police officer charged with manslaughter in the killing of an unarmed Palestinian man with autism in Jerusalem, a case that drew Palestinian outrage and focused attention on the treatment of Palestinians by Israeli police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Your Friday Briefing: Global Heat Shatters Records
description: Plus, Belarus’s president says Wagner’s leader is in Russia.
content: The past three days were quite likely the hottest in Earth’s modern history, scientists said, as an astonishing surge of heat across the globe continued to shatter temperature records from North America to Antarctica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully, Mike Ives and Elise Young
title: How 2 Firefighters Died in a Blaze They Were Ill-Equipped to Face
description: The fire broke out on a ship carrying more than 1,000 vehicles, owned by an Italian company and anchored at Port Newark.
content: The 9:30 p.m. call for help came from a place where firefighters from Newark are seldom sent: Port Newark, one of the busiest shipping hubs in the country, and one that operates largely as a world unto itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Advertisers Pay Attention as Meta’s Twitter Rival Surges
description: The technology giant’s new social network, Threads, pulled in more than 10 million sign-ups within hours of making its debut.
content: Threads made its debut on Wednesday night with a bang. Meta’s new social network had already racked up more than 10 million sign-ups within seven hours of its launch, and attracted celebrities and politicians like Oprah Winfrey and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: List Prices Are Creeping Downward After Years of Inflation
description: Is the tiny change a pivotal moment in the housing market?
content: After years of steady increases, the median list price for a home in the United States has finally dropped — if only a little, according to Realtor.com’s June Housing Report. The 0.9 percent decrease is the first downward movement reported since the company began publishing its trends research in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Winston
title: The Little-Known Provision That Could Revolutionize Highway Travel
description: Buried in the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act is a possible way to address all the costs associated with Americans’ love of driving.
content: It’s no small irony that so much federal money is being dedicated in various ways to climate-change projects that will do nothing to curtail Americans’ love of driving or to reduce the costs associated with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Amanda’ Review: My Loneliness Is Killing Me
description: A delusional college grad befriends an agoraphobic misanthrope in this stylish dark comedy by the Italian director Carolina Cavalli.
content: “Amanda,” a smart, stylish debut by the Italian writer-director Carolina Cavalli, plays like “Lady Bird” by way of Wes Anderson’s deadpan existentialism. Its heroine, the prickly Amanda (Benedetta Porcaroli), a college grad and the daughter of wealthy pharmacy owners, would rather twiddle her thumbs than work. Terrified of socializing with people her own age, she claims to prefer hanging out in the family chateau with her prepubescent niece and the maid. She would secretly kill for meaningful companionship — but first, she has to learn not to bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Here Lies Love’ Pairs Disco With a Dictator. It’s a Controversial Choice.
description: The musical, the brainchild of David Byrne and Fatboy Slim, dramatizes — and, some say, sanitizes — the life of the former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos.
content: The Broadway musical “Here Lies Love” is a rollicking karaoke dance party with an immersive staging and, for the first time in Broadway history, organizers say, an all-Filipino cast.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Colleges End Legacy Admissions?
description: Readers offer different views of a complaint against Harvard. Also: Lifesaving care; victim impact statements; relief from the gloom.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Steven Erlanger
title: NATO’s Welcome Party for Sweden Is Back on Ice
description: Alliance leaders wanted their summit next week to celebrate the arrival of a new member, but stalling by Hungary and objections from Turkey have made that nearly impossible.
content: For months, NATO leaders had hoped that when they convened for their annual summit next week, they could use the occasion to welcome Sweden as the alliance’s newest member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A Lot of Opera Is Now Streaming. Here’s Where to Start.
description: Naxos, which collects videos of productions throughout Europe, has begun to make its catalog available on Amazon Prime Video.
content: Opera isn’t so different from film and television in its glut of streaming platforms — which can be just as challenging, and expensive, to navigate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Elena Shao
title: Heat Records Are Broken Around the Globe as Earth Warms, Fast
description: From north to south, temperatures are surging as greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and combine with effects from El Niño.
content: The past three days were quite likely the hottest in Earth’s modern history, scientists said on Thursday, as an astonishing surge of heat across the globe continued to shatter temperature records from North America to Antarctica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: 2 Newark Firefighters Brought Years of Service to Their Final Fire
description: Augusto Acabou and Wayne Brooks Jr., who died fighting a blaze on a cargo ship, were products of Engine 16 in Newark’s Ironbound neighborhood.
content: When flames raced through a huge cargo ship in Port Newark in New Jersey on Wednesday, it was not some specialized nautical team that ventured into its blazing upper decks. It was city firefighters, whose last job might have been rushing to a burning house or fallen wires, or treating someone with chest pains or helping a woman in labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: What’s a Georgia Summer Without Peaches? Not So Sweet.
description: With their state’s signature crop hobbled by inclement weather, Georgians are stretching the fruit they have or turning (heaven forbid!) to California’s.
content: A darkness has fallen across the cobbler belt. You can barely find a peach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Alex Marshall
title: Studio Museum in Harlem and Other Clients Cut Ties to David Adjaye
description: Cultural institutions try to move projects forward without the star architect in the wake of sexual harassment allegations.
content: The Studio Museum in Harlem announced Thursday that it had taken the significant step of parting ways with David Adjaye, the charismatic Ghanaian British architect who is building its new home in Manhattan. A library project in Portland, Ore., is moving forward without him. A sculpture park in Lincoln, Mass., canceled a show of his work planned for fall. And other cultural institutions from Princeton, N.J., to Liverpool, England, expressed serious concerns in response to the allegations of sexual harassment and misconduct against Mr. Adjaye that surfaced this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Welcome to the Age of the Cage Match
description: These days, powerful men want to beat one another. Literally.
content: Call it the melee of the middle-aged men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean, Collins Chilumba Sampa and Gulshan Khan
title: Americans Tried to Save Elephants in Zambia. Were They the Good Guys?
description: A visit to a remote conservation park reveals the long-term impact on villagers of a crusade by the novelist Delia Owens and her husband to protect animals from poachers.
content: The hunter heard the helicopter coming. He grabbed his AK-47, he said, and jumped behind a tree. He was on an illegal elephant hunt with a group of men inside North Luangwa National Park in the southern African nation of Zambia. Smoke rose from the butchered meat that lay grilling on wooden racks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Judge Unseals More of Affidavit Used to Seek Mar-a-Lago Search Warrant
description: The newly disclosed sections revealed more of the evidence cited by the Justice Department as a basis for searching former President Donald J. Trump’s club and residence last summer.
content: A federal magistrate judge unsealed on Wednesday additional portions of the affidavit that the F.B.I. used last summer to obtain a warrant to search for sensitive documents at Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s private club and residence in Florida, revealing a few new details about how that extraordinary process had unfolded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: This week’s properties are three-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Sea Cliff, N.Y.
content: A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath 1,462-square-foot house, built in 2014, with radiant-heated floors and recessed lighting; a kitchen with two sinks, a double oven and an island with room for seating; a dining nook and piano alcove; a family room with a gas fireplace with marble surround, built-in cabinets and deck access; a two-person office with custom bamboo built-ins; an en suite primary bedroom with large windows, two closets, a glass-stall shower with a tub, and a balcony with pond views; a washer/dryer; and a deck that leads to the landscaped waterfront backyard, on 0.06 acres. Ellen Fusco, 203-257-7106; John Foran, 203-981-0785; Compass, compass.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell and Rowan Niemisto
title: Special Episode: Meta’s Twitter Rival Arrives, with Adam Mosseri
description: Instagram Threads — it’s like Twitter, except it’s not run by Elon Musk.
content: Instagram is no stranger to taking product ideas from other companies and turning them into their own successes. Just ask Snapchat about Instagram Stories or TikTok about Instagram Reels. This time, the company is coming for Twitter with Instagram Threads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Style Recap: Dressing Your Age
description: In the fourth episode of the season, Carrie bristles at the “our” in “women our age.”
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 4 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: In South Carolina, Biden Says His Agenda Has Helped Voters in Both Parties
description: President Biden cited Republican lawmakers who have attacked his policies but whose constituents have benefited from billions in federal funding.
content: President Biden outlined an economic agenda on Thursday that he believes has helped all voters, regardless of whether they voted for him, and name-checked Republican lawmakers who have attacked his policies but whose constituents have benefited from billions in federal funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jack Goldstein, a Savior of Broadway Theaters, Dies at 74
description: He helped secure landmark status for more than two dozen theaters in the 1980s, then initiated the design competition that led to a new TKTS booth.
content: Jack Goldstein, a preservationist who in the 1980s reacted to the razing of several venerable Broadway theaters under a Times Square redevelopment plan by helping to organize a successful campaign to give landmark status to more than two dozen other theaters, died on June 16 in Cold Spring, N.Y., in Putnam County. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: John Kerry to Visit China to Restart Climate Negotiations
description: A yearlong freeze in climate talks appears to be ending as the United States and China, the world’s biggest polluters, resume discussions.
content: WASHINGTON — John Kerry, President Biden’s special envoy for climate change, said on Thursday he would travel to China next week to restart global warming negotiations between the world’s two largest polluters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: What’s the Story With Colleen Hoover?
description: Her wildly popular romance novels offer a fantasy that feels attainable: self-actualization.
content: There are the novels the literary world acclaims and there are the novels people actually read. Occasionally — perhaps with decreasing frequency — they are one and the same. But apart from momentary blips when best seller and critical darling align (Colson Whitehead, Margaret Atwood, Ocean Vuong), they usually diverge. Every era has its authors whose novels are at best overlooked and at worst disparaged by the literary cognoscenti and still dominate best-seller lists. These books succeed not only despite the critics but almost as if to spite them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Marder
title: Uncoordinated? You Can Still Be an Athlete.
description: Many people avoid physical activity because they see themselves as clumsy. But, with practice, there are ways to fix that.
content: Carmen Chavez spent much of her life avoiding sports. Her aversion, she said, stemmed from the embarrassment of middle school gym class. As more athletic girls slammed volleyballs across the net, she worried about tripping or being hit by a ball. In order to avoid playing, she often sat on the sidelines and acted as the announcer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: banquet
description: This word has appeared in 135 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word banquet has appeared in 135 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 29 in the Opinion essay “I’ve Spent 28 Years Pondering the Wild World of My Home” by Margaret Renkl:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Ron DeSantis Is Running One Freaky Campaign
description: Rather than trying to lift people up, he seems to be running on contempt.
content: If you missed the previous newsletter, you can read it here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Lesson’ Review: Carefully Taut
description: A tense standoff between two writers kindles familial fireworks in this wittily self-aware melodrama.
content: No one is quite what they seem in “The Lesson,” Alice Troughton’s winking literary mystery whose languid summer setting — a swanky estate in the English countryside — hides coldly destructive secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: For Asian American Actors, Playing a Hot Mess Is Liberating
description: Forget the pious immigrant family drama. Films and shows like “Joy Ride,” “Beef” and “Shortcomings” are finally exploring all dimensions of the experience.
content: Ashley Park did not tell her mother much about the drugs, the sex or any of the other debauchery in “Joy Ride,” the over-the-top comedy in which she is co-starring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A meeting between the leaders of the U.S. and Sweden.
content: In less than a week, NATO leaders will meet in Vilnius, Lithuania. But the prime minister of Sweden will continue not to be among them, given the continued opposition of Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to Sweden’s membership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Winners of Our 6th Annual Student Podcast Contest
description: An oral history of Woodstock, an investigation into the origins of the fork, and an answer to the question of what makes a tune memorable. Listen to this year’s winning entries.
content: In our Student Podcast Contest, teenagers can cover any topic they want, in any audio format they like, as long as they provide a complete listening experience in five minutes or less. That freedom makes this contest a joy to judge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 6, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 6, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about an increase in tuna prices in Tunisia referred incorrectly to salata mechouia. While the dish includes grilled vegetables, it typically does not contain eggplant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Shootings in New York Drop by a Quarter as Surge of Violence Eases
description: Murders and rapes were also down, part of a nationwide trend after a post-pandemic spike.
content: Shootings in New York City dropped by about 25 percent through the first half of this year compared with the same period last year, extending a downward trend after a spike in violent crime during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Want a Last-Minute Ticket to Wimbledon? No Problem. Just Get in Line.
description: Thousands are waiting, even camping out, in rainy England for a chance to see one Wimbledon match. For some, it is an annual ritual, a pilgrimage for the love of tennis.
content: Tom O’Neill and Roz McArdle stood in Wimbledon’s famous ticketing queue with barely a hope of getting inside the grounds. It was 5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, there were 4,000 people ahead of them, and they were told by a steward that it was “enormously unlikely” they would get inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Threads Becomes Most Rapidly Downloaded App, Raising Twitter’s Ire
description: Instagram’s new app was downloaded more than 30 million times in 16 hours. Twitter threatened legal action against its rival.
content: Two hours after pressing the launch button on Wednesday on Threads, Instagram’s new app for real-time, public conversations, Mark Zuckerberg posted that more than two million people had downloaded his latest creation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Weighs Giving Ukraine Weapons Banned by Many U.S. Allies
description: Ukraine is seeking cluster munitions, which are known to cause grievous injuries to civilians, as its ammunition supply runs low.
content: For more than six months, President Biden and his aides have been wrestling with one of the most vexing questions in the war in Ukraine: whether to risk letting Ukrainian forces run out of the artillery rounds they desperately need to fight Russia, or agree to ship them cluster munitions — widely banned weapons known to cause grievous injury to civilians, especially children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Nations Aim to Zero Out Shipping Emissions by Midcentury
description: Regulators reached a provisional deal on how quickly the transition to zero-emissions fuels should happen for cargo ships, which often burn particularly dirty oil.
content: Negotiators from nearly every country reached a provisional agreement on Thursday to effectively eliminate the shipping industry’s greenhouse gas emissions by as close to 2050 as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Joy Ride’ Review: A Raunch-Com Roller Coaster
description: Four friends travel to China in a trip that goes entertainingly off the rails in this terrific comedy, starring Ashley Park and Sherry Cola.
content: The new “Joy Ride” offers a modern-comedy bingo card with pretty much all the squares checked: mismatched besties, an oddball crashing a group outing, said outing going wildly off the rails, freewheeling sex, projectile vomiting, unhinged debauchery involving booze and drugs, and a crucial plot point hinging on an intimate body part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: There’s One Hard Question My Fellow Doctors and I Will Need to Answer Soon
description: How will A.I. change how we practice medicine?
content: When faced with a particularly tough question on rounds during my intern year, I would run straight to the bathroom. There, I would flip through the medical reference book I carried in my pocket, find the answer and return to the group, ready to respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Becker
title: A Brutally Honest Exploration of What It Means to Be a War Reporter
description: In “No Ordinary Assignment,” the correspondent Jane Ferguson is candid about the fears and frustrations that come with her calling.
content: “Afghanistan was the Vietnam of our era,” Jane Ferguson writes in her memoir, “No Ordinary Assignment.” She sees her generation of reporters as descendants of the men and women who covered the first war the United States lost to a largely rural Asian nation. In both cases, America had the overwhelming military advantage of a superpower’s arsenal and the political disadvantage of a superpower’s hubris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Kennedy, Christie and the Supreme Court: Are They Changing the Race?
description: A painful ruling from the court can sometimes free a party from an unpopular stance.
content: When I returned from a trip to China almost exactly eight years ago, I found my inbox full of requests from editors to write about two huge stories that unfolded while I was gone: the Supreme Court’s decision to legalize same-sex marriage and the emergence of a surprising candidate who entered the race after my departure, Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Abortion Drugs May Be Safe Even After the First Trimester, Study Suggests
description: Most women who took abortion medications were successful, often at later gestation periods. Many used only misoprostol, not the usual two-drug combination.
content: An overwhelming majority of women were able to end unwanted pregnancies with abortion medications on their own and without additional medical procedures, even if they were well beyond the first trimester, according to a report published on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Pieces of Munich Synagogue, Destroyed on Hitler’s Orders, Found in River
description: The demolition of the city’s main synagogue was an early sign of the terrible destruction to come under the Nazi regime.
content: Eighty-five years ago, Munich’s main synagogue was demolished on direct orders from Adolf Hitler — a terrible harbinger of the destruction to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: OceanGate, Operator of the Titan Submersible, Suspends Operations
description: The company made the announcement weeks after a dive to the wreckage of the Titanic presumably imploded, killing five people.
content: OceanGate Expeditions said it had “suspended all exploration and commercial operations” after its Titan submersible presumably imploded during a dive to explore the wreckage of the Titanic last month, killing the company’s founder and four other people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Chris Paul Knows All About the Cycle of Life
description: For the veteran N.B.A. point guard, publication month was a bittersweet mash-up of change, celebration and family.
content: Chris Paul has had an eventful few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: For Filipino Audiences, ‘Here Lies Love’ Offers Emotional Rip Currents
description: For viewers as well as the all-Filipino cast, the musical about the Marcoses’ rise to power is a rare chance to commune, and revisit, together, a not-too-distant past.
content: The disco balls were spinning, the club music was pulsing, and on the dance floor, several Filipino audience members were near tears.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cost of ‘Financial Trauma’? A Distorted View of Money.
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 6, 2023.
content: “It can feel like watching a scary movie all over again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Los Angeles Hotel Employees Return to Work but Warn of Additional Strikes
description: The hotel workers’ strike is the latest in a wave of labor actions by employees in California in what labor leaders are calling a “hot labor summer.”
content: Thousands of housekeepers, front desk clerks, cooks and other hospitality staff returned to work on Wednesday at hotels in the Los Angeles area after three days of picketing, but union leaders said that more walkouts are likely in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Sherman
title: In Paris, a Dinner at a Former Taxidermy Workshop
description: The traveling culinary studio We Are Ona laid down roots in its founder Luca Pronzato’s home city and invited friends to celebrate.
content: For the past four years, the culinary studio We Are Ona has been converting unconventional spaces around the world — the 31st floor of a New York City office building, a tennis court in Milan, the onetime atelier of a 19th-century French photographer — into temporary restaurants. Some operate for just a night, others for up to six months, and the studio’s founder, Luca Pronzato, 31, approaches each one as an elaborate, site-specific production, relying on an international crew of chefs, artisans, designers and florists to bring his vision to life. Though he’s organized 30 ticketed public pop-ups and over a hundred private culinary events, he’s never done the same thing twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Long Island Steps Up Shark Patrols After Swimmers Are Bitten
description: The authorities in Suffolk County said they responded to three shark bites off Fire Island over a two-day period this week.
content: Officials on Long Island have stepped up shark patrols after authorities responded to several reports of people being bitten by sharks in separate locations around the July 4 holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Hawaii Shop Turning Oahu’s Invasive Trees Into Surfboards
description: Plus: home décor from Ulla Johnson, a restaurant in a vintage airstream and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: This spring, the chef Molly Levine began serving seasonal cuisine from a refurbished 1971 Airstream trailer parked on a former dairy farm in the Hudson Valley. Westerly Canteen’s trailer holds a compact kitchen with cream-painted walls and blond wood counters. “I had this wild idea, like, ‘What if we took the food truck concept and put it in a space that is still mobile but feels beautiful and welcoming?’” Levine said as she stirred a pot of golden-hued stock, fragrant with spring onion and green garlic. Levine, who previously worked at the Berkeley, Calif., restaurant Chez Panisse, founded Westerly with her partner, Alex Kaindl, a farmer who tends half an acre in Sharon, Conn. Nearly all of their ingredients are sourced from farms nearby. (Starting this month, Kaindl’s crops will also be incorporated.) Developing the weekly menu is a puzzle that requires maximizing limited space and resources. “A lot of our decisions are very creative and passion driven but also very practical,” Kaindl said as Levine ladled the stock over a plate of nettle-stuffed ravioli. “We slice up the spring onions that go into the dish, and the tops are made into the broth,” Levine said. “We’re using every piece of the onion.” The founders hope to engage the surrounding community while also drawing diners from afar. They’ve partnered with Tenmile Distillery, which offers cocktails made with local ingredients to go alongside Westerly’s menu (their take on a Negroni includes Faccia Brutto bitters from Brooklyn, Method sweet vermouth from Romulus and gin made on-site at Tenmile). “We really want people to sit here and stay a while,” Levine said. westerlycanteen.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: America, Shall I Compare Thee to a Chevy Volt?
description: Move over, apple pie. We’re picking new American symbols.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Can A.I. Be Funny? This Troupe Thinks So.
description: ComedyBytes, a New York-based group, uses artificial intelligence to shape what makes audiences laugh.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at a New York-based comedy group that is using artificial intelligence to generate jokes. And we’ll bring you highlights from an interview with former Mayor Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, on their separation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Ex-Prisoners Face Headwinds as Job Seekers, Even as Openings Abound
description: An estimated 60 percent of those leaving prison are unemployed a year later. But after a push for “second-chance hiring,” some programs show promise.
content: The U.S. unemployment rate is hovering near lows unseen since the 1960s. A few months ago, there were roughly two job openings for every unemployed person in the country. Many standard economic models suggest that almost everyone who wants a job has a job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen: Serial’s New Episode, Twitter’s Rival Arrives, ‘Bridget Jones’s Diary’
description: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
content: We hope you’ve started Serial’s new series, The Retrievals, about the shocking events that unfolded at a Yale fertility clinic, because Episode 2 is out now. Also, don’t miss a special Hard Fork episode with Instagram’s chief executive about the platform’s new competitor to Twitter. And how far would you travel to find your mother’s con man?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tour de France Becomes a ‘Big, Big Battle’ Between Pogacar and Vingegaard
description: The two favorites traded attacks in punishing stages in the Pyrenees.
content: Everyone expected this year’s Tour de France to be a two-cyclist race between the defending champion, Jonas Vingegaard of Denmark, and the 2020 and 2021 winner, Tadej Pogacar of Slovenia. And everyone expected the first true test for them to come on Days 5 and 6 in the Pyrenees mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rikki Novetsky, Mary Wilson, Stella Tan, Michael Benoist, Rachel Quester, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Russia After the Rebellion
description: What Vladimir Putin’s reaction to the Wagner mutiny indicates about the state of his power.
content: Last month, a rebellion inside Russia left lingering questions about what really happened and about what the ramifications would be for President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Douglas Stuart Doesn’t Need 3 People at His Dream Dinner Party
description: “I regret that I never met Hilary Mantel,” says the Booker-winning Scottish novelist, whose most recent book, “Young Mungo,” is now out in paperback. “I would be delighted with three of her.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Isaacs, Rachel A. Schwartz and Álvaro Montenegro
title: If the Election Deniers Succeed, Guatemala Will Have Lost the Battle for Democracy
description: Though the country’s autocrats have now deployed the full force of the state to steal the elections, they are not the only people mobilizing.
content: Guatemala’s democracy is under assault. Over the past four years, a group of powerful elites tied to organized crime, known as the “pact of the corrupt,” has been steadily dismantling Guatemala’s democratic guardrails by co-opting judicial institutions and arresting and exiling prosecutors, judges, journalists and pro-democracy activists. Now, in their next step to consolidate power, they are trying to manipulate the national elections that are underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: At Least 16 Are Killed in Suspected Gas Leak in South Africa
description: A cylinder with a type of gas often linked to illegal mining was found in a shack at an encampment near the city of Boksburg, an official said.
content: JOHANNESBURG — At least 16 people were killed in a gas leak at an informal housing encampment on the outskirts of Johannesburg, the police said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: They Hold Weeds, and an Artist’s Sublime Vision
description: The ceramist Doyle Lane created a universe of colors and shapes with his ‘weed pots,’ 100 of which form his first solo show in New York, at David Kordansky.
content: The David Kordansky Gallery has mounted a wonderful wormhole of an exhibition, “Doyle Lane: Weed Pots.” Its point of access is the small unassuming “weed pot,” a frequent accent in modern California interiors starting in the late 1950s. Thrown on a wheel, Lane’s pots were rarely more than 3 or 4 inches high, spherical or elliptical in volume and usually topped by a short, narrow neck, small mouth and turned lip, designed to hold a dried sprig of weed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: What to Know if You’re Considering the Alzheimer’s Drug Leqembi
description: Medicare will cover much of the cost for patients in the early stages of the disease, but Leqembi has safety risks and can only modestly slow cognitive decline.
content: On Thursday, the Food and Drug Administration gave full approval to the drug Leqembi for patients who are in the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease, and Medicare said it would cover 80 percent of the cost of the $26,500-per-year medication. The decisions by the two federal agencies will vastly increase access to the drug but also present a dilemma for patients and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: German Businesses Bet Big on China, and They’re Starting to Worry
description: Geopolitical risks have exposed long-ignored strains on Germany’s socioeconomic model. The family businesses underpinning its economy are seeking a new path.
content: Amid the ruins of a city ravaged by World War II, Karl Haeusgen’s grandfather invented a hydraulic pump he was so proud of that he founded a company to sell it. Back then, there were no revenue projections or five-year growth strategies. The plan was survival: “It was just about grabbing chances,” Mr. Haeusgen said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Rage and Joy of MAGA America
description: Come for the community. Stay for the vituperation.
content: I’ve shared this fact with readers before: I live in Tennessee outside Nashville, a very deep-red part of America. According to a New York Times tool that calculates the political composition of a community, only 15 percent of my neighbors are Democrats. I’ve been living here in the heart of MAGA country since Donald Trump came down the escalator. This is the world of my friends, my neighbors and many members of my family. That is perhaps why, when I’m asked what things are like now, eight years into the Trump era, I have a ready answer: Everything is normal until, suddenly, it’s not. And unless we can understand what’s normal and what’s not, we can’t truly understand why Trumpism endures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Prigozhin Is Said to Be in Russia, as Wagner Mystery Deepens
description: After the mercenary boss staged a brief insurrection in Russia, the leader of Belarus said his country had taken him in, but now says the Wagner leader was in St. Petersburg and then “maybe he went to Moscow.”
content: The mercenary leader Yevgeny V. Prigozhin is in Russia and is a “free man” despite staging a rebellion against Moscow’s military leadership, the leader of Belarus said on Thursday, deepening the mystery of where Mr. Prigozhin and his Wagner group stand and what will become of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Rossi and Maria Jimenez Moya
title: Where 9-Year-Olds Do 60 M.P.H.
description: For kids who dream of racing professionally, steering go-karts around a twisting track is where it all begins.
content: On the second day of the Texas Grand Prix, motors were roaring. As mechanics tinkered with vehicles, drivers talked strategy with their coaches and tried to memorize the curves of the racetrack at the Speedsportz Racing Park outside Houston. “I imagine it in my brain,” said Mikey Collins as he waited for his heat to start on the last weekend in April. “I envision it and try to do laps.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Andrés R. Martínez
title: A Russian missile strike kills six people in Lviv.
description: The authorities said more than 30 people had been injured and warned that there could still be people trapped under the rubble.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian missiles killed at least six people and destroyed dozens of homes in Lviv before dawn on Thursday, in what officials said was the biggest attack on the western Ukrainian city since Russia launched its full-scale invasion more than 16 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyn Hejinian and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: Time of Tyranny, 49
description: Lyn Hejinian’s sonnet proposes that liberation might be found in scattering and disorientation.
content: Lyn Hejinian’s poem has the sonnet’s traditional 14 lines and even features the sonnet’s coupletlike resolution, but the length of its lines exceeds tradition, nearly reaching to the very edges of line itself. It borrows prose’s linear momentum but refuses the carelessness of prose’s wraparound ends. The power of these lines is, in part, generated by their quick liftoffs — each begins with a word of a single syllable. This is paired with cunning line breaks that enjamb, suggest, double the words that surround them and intensify the effect of the poem by giving it both vertical and horizontal motion. Throughout, there is thick sound stacked on thick sound, the diction mixed and surprising, the everyday and the erudite sparking like flint and steel. In my reading of the poem, it is as if the line is seeking to enact the poem’s proposition: that in the motion of scattering, in an orientation of disorientation, a possibility of liberation might be found.  Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Stone Fruit Every Which Way
description: In almond upside-down cake, in caprese with creamy mozzarella and lightly pickled with labneh.
content: The text was brief: “Warning: She made you a cake.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, on the Upper West Side and in Long Island City.
content: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, roughly 3,400-square-foot apartment with formal living and dining rooms, built-in cabinets, a wood-burning fireplace, an eat-in kitchen and a powder room on the first level; an en suite primary bedroom, two additional en suite bedrooms and walk-in closets on the second level; plus a washer/dryer and private elevator, in a 38-story doorman building with a concierge, valet, gym, Pilates studio, golf simulator, conference rooms, bike room, shared laundry, extra storage and two decks. Arlene Reed and Rebecca Blacker, Coldwell Banker Warburg, 917-373-8343; cbwarburg.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cesar Rodriguez and Elda Cantú
title: What 120 Degrees Looks Like in One of Mexico’s Hottest Cities
description: During the most recent heat wave, residents of the northern city of Hermosillo struggled to breathe in the scorching temperatures.
content: People in Hermosillo are used to the heat: Enduring scorching temperatures is a local point of pride in this northwestern Mexican city known for its blistering weather and nicknamed the “city of sun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: At Glamorous French Festivals, Poverty Is Only Onstage
description: The opening productions of the Avignon and Aix-en-Provence Festivals brought tales of the down-and-out to well-heeled spectators. It got awkward.
content: Two events tower over France’s summer festival season each July, held in cities less than 50 miles apart. One, the Avignon Festival, is a bustling, overcrowded celebration of theater; the other, the Aix-en-Provence Festival, offers a more genteel operatic lineup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Out-Laws’ Review: Adam Devine, Funny at Last
description: Devine channels Jack Lemmon as a law-abiding Everyman whose fiancée’s parents rob the bank he manages. (Awkward.)
content: You can really see Adam Devine going for the Jack Lemmon vibes in his latest vehicle, “The Out-Laws.” As Owen Browning, a tidy but slightly schlubby suburban Everyman with an impending wedding, he meets adversity with a broad grin and an implied ambition to ingratiate himself to the whole world. So a superficial Jack Lemmon vibe — except Jack Lemmon never twerked in boxer shorts. Not that he necessarily would have considered it beneath him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: 5 Noteworthy Falsehoods Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Has Promoted
description: A longtime vaccine skeptic, Mr. Kennedy is leaning heavily on misinformation as he mounts a long-shot 2024 campaign.
content: He has promoted a conspiracy theory that coronavirus vaccines were developed to control people via microchips. He has endorsed the false notion that antidepressants are linked to school shootings. And he has pushed the decades-old theory that the C.I.A. killed his uncle, former President John F. Kennedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: The ruble hits early war lows, extending a slide that began after Prigozhin’s mutiny.
description: The ruble fell as low as 94 rubles per dollar on Thursday before making a slight recovery by the end of the trading day.
content: The Russian ruble slid to lows unseen since the weeks after Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine, amid fallout from the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s aborted insurrection and declining Russian oil and gas revenues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Rich Are Crazier Than You and Me
description: Why does Silicon Valley love RFK Jr.?
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is a crank. His views are a mishmash of right-wing fantasies mixed with remnants of the progressive he once was: Bitcoin boosterism, anti-vaccine conspiracy theories, assertions that Prozac causes mass shootings, opposition to U.S. support for Ukraine, but also favorable mention for single-payer health care. But for his last name, nobody would be paying him any attention — and despite that last name, he has zero chance of winning the Democratic presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Hass
title: Xi Jinping May Be Souring on His ‘Best, Most Intimate Friend’
description: How Putin’s leadership troubles have implications for China.
content: When Xi Jinping ascended to the pinnacle of Chinese power a decade ago, he saw Vladimir Putin as a strong leader who shared his hostility to the Western-dominated international system. They bonded over mutual paranoia about threats to their rule and exchanged best practices for imposing control at home and making the world more accommodating of their authoritarian impulses. Mr. Xi referred to Mr. Putin as his “best, most intimate friend.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Yankees Pitcher Suspended for Violating Domestic Violence Policy
description: Jimmy Cordero, a reliever, will miss the rest of the season after an investigation led by Major League Baseball.
content: Jimmy Cordero, a relief pitcher for the Yankees, has been suspended for the rest of the season for violating Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy, the league and the team announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Winnie Ewing, Who Transformed Scottish Politics, Dies at 93
description: Her charismatic nationalism made independence from Britain a mainstream idea. She championed that idea for her many decades in office.
content: Winnie Ewing, who in the late 1960s transformed Scottish politics by bringing the issue of independence from Britain to the national mainstream from the electoral fringe, died on June 21 at her home in Bridge of Weir, a town west of Glasgow. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and David McCabe
title: Ruling Puts Social Media at Crossroads of Disinformation and Free Speech
description: The case, which could alter how the government battles disinformation, is a flashpoint in a broader effort by conservatives to document what they contend is a liberal conspiracy to silence their views.
content: Two months after President Biden took office, his top digital adviser emailed officials at Facebook urging them to do more to limit the spread of “vaccine hesitancy” on the social media platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: How Tom Brady’s Crypto Ambitions Collided With Reality
description: The superstar quarterback is among the celebrities dealing with the fallout from the crypto crash. Others, like Taylor Swift, escaped.
content: As the FTX cryptocurrency exchange imploded last fall, Tom Brady, the seven-time Super Bowl-winning quarterback, made an urgent phone call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Burton, Laura Starecheski, Julie Snyder and Carla Pallone
title: Episode 2: The Nurse
description: From Serial Productions. Patients know what happened to them at the clinic. Now they find out who did it.
content: The patients who underwent painful egg retrievals at a Yale clinic know what happened to them: Fentanyl intended for use during their procedures had been replaced with saline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The Crossed ‘Signals’ of MoMA’s Largest Ever Video Show
description: Full of experiments with new media, the museum’s giant exhibition displays the powers and the pitfalls of seeing the world through a screen.
content: Beauty is nice, elegance has its place, but sometimes I go to museums to be perplexed: to agree and disagree, to argue and reassess, to leave even less certain than I was before. I sure got my wish with “Signals: How Video Transformed the World,” which closes this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art — and which, screen for screen, hour for hour, stands proud as the most perplexing exhibition of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: 6 Paris Bistros to Try Now
description: The city’s restaurant scene is back in full force, and a half-dozen bistro-style eateries showcase the best of what’s new, including a refreshingly simple style of cooking.
content: Paris has recovered its scents, and the city is suddenly ravenous. The whiffs of shallots sautéing in butter, bread baking, meat roasting and bouillon simmering that invisibly punctuate any stroll in this food-loving city are back. In fact, the French capital is in the midst of a restaurant boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niela Orr
title: What’s Lost When Censors Tamper With Classic Films
description: A new edit of ‘The French Connection’ removes a racial slur. But nit-picking old artworks for breaking today’s rules inevitably makes it harder to see the complete picture.
content: The remarkable thing about the censored scene is how ordinary it feels if you've watched a police procedural made before, say, 2010. It’s in William Friedkin’s “The French Connection,” from 1971. Two narcotics cops — Jimmy (Popeye) Doyle, played by Gene Hackman, and Buddy (Cloudy) Russo, played by Roy Scheider — are at the precinct, following an undercover operation during which a drug dealer ended up slashing Russo with a knife. The injury has left Russo struggling to put on his coat. “Need a little help there?” Doyle chuckles, then adds an ethnic jab: “You dumb guinea.” Russo: “How the hell did I know he had a knife?” Here Doyle points a slur at the Black dealer: “Never trust a nigger.” Russo: “He could have been white.” Doyle: “Never trust anyone.” Then he invites Russo out for a drink, and they trade masturbation jokes as they head through the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: L. Lin Wood, Lawyer Who Tried to Overturn Trump’s 2020 Loss, Gives Up License
description: Mr. Wood wrote that the Georgia State Bar had “agreed to drop the disciplinary cases” against him if he retired from the profession.
content: L. Lin Wood, one of the key lawyers who sought to overturn former President Donald J. Trump’s 2020 election loss and faced potential disciplinary action in Georgia as a result, opted to give up his law license in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Car Crashes Into London School, Killing 8-Year-Old Girl
description: The driver of the vehicle that smashed into a private elementary school for girls has been arrested. Officials were not treating it as terrorism-related.
content: An 8-year-old girl was killed and several others were injured on Thursday when a vehicle crashed into a private elementary school for girls in the southwestern London suburb of Wimbledon, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: The seeds for this week’s recommended books were planted last winter, when editors at the Book Review noticed a heavier than usual concentration of excellent literature in translation coming down the pipeline. One thing led to another, and we ended up with a whole issue devoted to the topic, filled with books that will take you around the world thanks to the efforts of the translators who brought them into English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Once Upon a Time in Uganda’ Review: When Ragtag Met Rambo
description: A new documentary tells how a Ugandan filmmaker and an American producer have reshaped African cinema.
content: Wakaliwood is more than a production house; it’s a spirit of ragtag moviemaking born from the pure desire to create. Founded in 2005 by the writer-director Isaac Nabwana and based in Wakaliga, a slum in Kampala, Uganda, the studio produces low-budget, hyperviolent action films inspired by “Rambo” and Chuck Norris but starring African actors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The YouTube Effect’ Review: Tracing a Platform’s Cultural Footprint
description: Alex Winter offers an overview of the world’s second most popular website in this unfocused tech documentary.
content: The numbing experience of web video surfing is recreated — intentionally, I think — in “The YouTube Effect,” a discursive documentary that assembles a fair amount of information about the impact of YouTube on society, but struggles to find something new to say with it. Directed by Alex Winter, the film charts the rise of the video sharing platform and then attempts to trace its Sasquatch-size footprint on the culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Ryan Mac
title: F.B.I. Searched the Home of Crypto Exchange Founder
description: Federal agents were investigating Jesse Powell, the founder of the crypto exchange Kraken, over claims that he hacked and cyber-stalked a nonprofit arts group.
content: The F.B.I. searched the home of the cryptocurrency executive Jesse Powell in March as part of a criminal investigation into claims that he hacked and cyber-stalked a nonprofit that he founded, three people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Orthodox Men Dominate Mayor Adams’s New Jewish Advisory Council
description: A majority of the advisers are Orthodox and only a quarter are women, drawing criticism from Jewish leaders including Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York.
content: If there is an archetypical Jewish New Yorker, that person might be found on the Upper West Side, somewhere between Zabar’s and Barney Greengrass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: How Style Not Com Became the Darling of the Front Row
description: Beka Gvishiani started as a fan, with little access to powerful people in fashion. Now he’s at every show.
content: What does it take these days to become one of the most sought-after people reporting from fashion’s front row? Beka Gvishiani, the man behind the hit Instagram account Style Not Com, will tell you, in the same straightforward language that defines Style Not Com, nostalgically named for Style.com, the groundbreaking Condé Nast site that brought runway fashion to the internet in 2000. (Style.com shut down and morphed into Vogue Runway in 2015.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: You Told Us About the Best Part of Your Year So Far
description: Among your delightful responses: whale sightings, a spectacular 80th birthday party, falling in love and graduations that didn’t come easy.
content: To find some relief in a world that too often feels tumultuous and deeply fractured, I’ve recently been trying to cultivate more delight in my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps and John Ismay
title: U.S. Is Destroying the Last of Its Once-Vast Chemical Weapons Arsenal
description: Decades behind its initial schedule, the dangerous job of eliminating the world’s only remaining declared stockpile of lethal chemical munitions will be completed as soon as Friday.
content: In a sealed room behind a gantlet of armed guards and three rows of high barbed wire at the Army’s Pueblo Chemical Depot in Colorado, a team of robotic arms was busily disassembling some of the last of the United States’ vast and ghastly stockpile of chemical weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: The ‘Great Resignation’ Is Over. Can Workers’ Power Endure?
description: The furious pace of job-switching in recent years has led to big gains for low-wage workers. But the pendulum could be swinging back toward employers.
content: Tens of millions of Americans have changed jobs over the past two years, a tidal wave of quitting that reflected — and helped create — a rare moment of worker power as employees demanded higher pay, and as employers, short on staff, often gave it to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Federal Judge Defends Clarence Thomas in New Book
description: Judge Amul Thapar assiduously defends the Supreme Court justice but says courts should foster greater public understanding of how they work.
content: Judge Amul Thapar thinks America is misjudging its judges — one in particular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Hudson Tunnel Project to Get $6.9 Billion in Largest U.S. Transit Grant
description: The federal funding would allow work on the long-delayed Gateway tunnel to start by next year, said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York.
content: The federal government is on track to give $6.88 billion, the most ever awarded to a mass-transit project, for the construction of a second rail tunnel under the Hudson River to New York City, Senator Chuck Schumer said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: This Was No Ordinary Sunburn. What Was Wrong?
description: The man always loved to bask in the sun. Now, at 80, the rays were making his skin red and itchy.
content: “Come in out of the sun,” the woman shouted to her 80-year-old husband. “You’re turning red!” The man reluctantly trudged toward the house. It was late afternoon — the end of a glorious summer day in Orange, Conn. But when he glanced down at his exposed arms, he could see that she was right. He was a bright pink, and soon he knew his arms and probably the back of his neck would be red and itchy. It was time to go inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Eton College Wrestles With Change in a More Modern Britain
description: The youngest headmaster in the history of the English boarding school that has educated the British elite for centuries tries to navigate a tightrope between tradition and evolution.
content: At Eton College — the boarding school in the British countryside that has educated princes and 20 prime ministers — students wear tailcoats and white ties to classes. But some have worn waistcoats with the symbol of Black History Month underneath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: “Insecure” has made its way to Netflix. Otherwise, check out an Agatha Christie mystery adapted and directed by Hugh Laurie.
content: ‘Insecure’When to watch: Now, on Netflix or Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: In Film and Television, Food for Thought and Interpretation
description: Tejal Rao uses her experience as a restaurant critic to write about food served onscreen.
content: Italian beef sandwiches, fruit-studded buns and Flamin’ Hot Cheetos have been top of mind for Tejal Rao lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Caesarean Delivery
description: Alison Perch makes a lovely New York Times Crossword debut while giving me emotional whiplash.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Job Openings Dipped in May, a Sign of Continued Cooling
description: Hiring was largely unchanged, and the number of workers quitting their jobs increased. The data will be watched closely by Federal Reserve policymakers.
content: Job openings fell in May while the number of workers quitting their jobs increased, the Labor Department reported Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: When the Street Moves to the Opera House (and Subverts It)
description: The French choreographer Bintou Dembélé brings her desire to create “a fair ecosystem” to the Avignon Festival, which she opened with “G.R.O.O.V.E.”
content: In 2019, Bintou Dembélé, a hip-hop pioneer in France, became the first Black female choreographer to be hired by the Paris Opera. Two years later, during a residency in Chicago, she discovered an English word that has no equivalent in French: “tokenism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: We Are Breaking Heat Records Around the World
description: Also, Prigozhin is in Russia. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: An astonishing surge of heat across the globe has shattered temperature records from North America to Antarctica. Scientists say the past three days were quite likely the hottest in Earth’s modern history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Chloé Bids Goodbye to Gabriela Hearst
description: The designer’s departure from the French fashion house is the latest in a string of exits at the top of the luxury industry this year.
content: After months of speculation, Chloé said its creative director, Gabriela Hearst, was leaving the French fashion house after a three-year tenure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Biosphere’ Review: It’s the End of the World (and They Caused It)
description: What happens when a petulant, anti-intellectual president destroys the planet and he and his childhood buddy, the brainy one, are the only survivors?
content: Over the decades that Billy (Mark Duplass) and Ray (Sterling K. Brown) have been best buds, the world has gotten worse — and they’re to blame. Honestly. “Biosphere,” a honed yet heartfelt two-person dramedy by the first-time feature director Mel Eslyn, takes place in a geodesic dome under a black sky. A few years back, Billy, then president of the United States, destroyed the planet; luckily, his consigliere, Ray, had already built this bunker. Barring a miracle, it will be humanity’s final tomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Ana Ley
title: Food-Delivery Companies Sue New York City Over Minimum Pay Law
description: Uber, DoorDash and Grubhub argued that the city used poor data to calculate how much food delivery workers should earn and that the change would hurt consumers.
content: Three food-delivery giants are suing New York City to block minimum pay standards for gig workers, arguing that regulators used faulty data to calculate the new compensation rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Does New Hampshire Go First?
description: New Hampshire has a strikingly poor record of identifying the strongest Democratic presidential candidates.
content: The Democratic Party is engaged in a roiling debate over the order of its presidential primaries, as a Times Magazine story by Ross Barkan explains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: 3 Easy Dishes, One Near-Effortless Summer Dinner Party
description: Turmeric potato salad, smoky pork chops and lemony shortcakes: These recipes from David Tanis are as bright and refreshing as the season should be.
content: A few thoughts about summer cooking: It should be bold, flavorful, refreshing. It should take full advantage of the season’s fresh produce. And, if possible, it should be consumed outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: 36 Hours in the Florida Panhandle
description: Pick your own paradise along State Road 30A, long a beloved vacation destination for Southerners.
content: Pick your own paradise along State Road 30A, long a beloved vacation destination for Southerners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: Mulling Manhattan One-Bedrooms: Prewar Charm or Modern Amenities?
description: A couple of longtime renters searched the West Side for a condo that could accommodate a comfortable work-from-home setup. Here’s what they found.
content: A couple of longtime renters searched the West Side for a condo that could accommodate a comfortable work-from-home setup. Here’s what they found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
description: Cyclists keep climbing through the Tour de France, while golfers and soccer players take their turns in the spotlight.
content: Cyclists keep climbing through the Tour de France, while golfers and soccer players take their turns in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Two Firefighters Die in Blaze on Cargo Ship in Newark
description: Firefighters responded to a fire on a cargo ship docked at Port Newark, which was carrying more than a thousand vehicles when the blaze started.
content: Firefighters responded to a fire on a cargo ship docked at Port Newark, which was carrying more than a thousand vehicles when the blaze started.
source.name: The New York Times
